title: Server Startup - Recruit Refresh
description:
On server start, check recruit listing age and generate new batch if expired. Should be idempotent (safe to run every restart).

## Current State
- RecruiterRefreshJob exists and handles the 30-90 min refresh cycle
- Job: cleans expired recruits, generates pool per tier/class
- Schedule: self-schedules via set(wait: rand(30..90).minutes)
- Recruit model: available_at, expires_at timestamps

## Problem
- Job only runs if manually triggered or if already scheduled
- On server restart, no recruits may exist or job may not be queued
- Need idempotent startup hook to ensure recruits exist

## Goal
1. On Rails server boot, check if recruits need refresh
2. If pool is empty or expired, generate fresh batch
3. Ensure job is scheduled for next rotation
4. Must be safe to run on every restart (idempotent)

title: Create recruit pool health check method
description:
Add class method to Recruit for checking pool health:

```ruby
class Recruit < ApplicationRecord
  # Check if recruit pool needs refresh
  # @return [Boolean] true if pool is empty, stale, or understocked
  def self.needs_refresh?
    # No available recruits at all
    return true if available_now.empty?
    
    # Check each active tier has minimum recruits
    active_tiers = User.distinct.pluck(:level_tier).compact
    active_tiers.any? do |tier|
      NPC_CLASSES.any? do |npc_class|
        available_for_tier(tier).where(npc_class: npc_class).count < MIN_POOL_SIZE
      end
    end
  end
  
  MIN_POOL_SIZE = 3 # Minimum per class/tier before refresh
  
  scope :available_now, -> { 
    where('available_at <= ? AND expires_at > ?', Time.current, Time.current) 
  }
end
```

title: Add idempotent startup method to RecruiterRefreshJob
description:
Add class method for safe startup invocation:

```ruby
class RecruiterRefreshJob < ApplicationJob
  # Idempotent startup check - safe to call on every boot
  # Only performs refresh if pool needs it
  # Only schedules if no job already enqueued
  def self.ensure_running!
    return unless Recruit.needs_refresh?
    
    # Check if job already scheduled (implementation depends on queue adapter)
    # For Solid Queue: check solid_queue_jobs table
    # For simple case: just run synchronously on boot
    
    Rails.logger.info '[RecruiterRefreshJob] Pool needs refresh, running...'
    perform_now
  end
end
```

Alternative: Always run on boot (cleanup + generate is idempotent anyway).

title: Create Rails initializer for recruit refresh
description:
Create config/initializers/recruit_refresh.rb:

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

# Ensure recruit pool is populated on server startup
# This is idempotent - safe to run on every boot

Rails.application.config.after_initialize do
  # Skip in test environment and rake tasks
  next if Rails.env.test?
  next if defined?(Rails::Console)
  next unless defined?(Rails::Server) || ENV['ENSURE_RECRUITS']
  
  # Run on separate thread to not block boot
  Thread.new do
    sleep 5 # Wait for DB connections to stabilize
    
    Rails.logger.info '[Startup] Checking recruit pool...'
    RecruiterRefreshJob.ensure_running!
    Rails.logger.info '[Startup] Recruit pool check complete'
  rescue => e
    Rails.logger.error "[Startup] Recruit refresh failed: \#{e.message}"
  end
end
```

Alternative: Use config.after_initialize with ActiveJob.perform_later for async.

title: Add job deduplication to prevent multiple scheduled jobs
description:
Prevent multiple RecruiterRefreshJob from being scheduled:

Option 1 - Database flag:
```ruby
# Add scheduled_job_tokens table or use cache
def schedule_next_run
  return if next_run_scheduled?
  
  delay_minutes = rand(30..90)
  RecruiterRefreshJob.set(wait: delay_minutes.minutes).perform_later
  mark_scheduled!
end
```

Option 2 - Use Solid Queue unique jobs (if available)

Option 3 - Check queue before scheduling:
```ruby
def schedule_next_run
  # Skip if already scheduled (adapter-specific)
  return if SolidQueue::Job.where(class_name: 'RecruiterRefreshJob')
                           .where('scheduled_at > ?', Time.current)
                           .exists?
  
  RecruiterRefreshJob.set(wait: rand(30..90).minutes).perform_later
end
```

Choose based on queue adapter in use.

title: Add tests for recruit startup flow
description:
Test the idempotent startup behavior:

test/jobs/recruiter_refresh_job_test.rb:
```ruby
test 'ensure_running! generates recruits when pool empty' do
  Recruit.delete_all
  assert Recruit.needs_refresh?
  
  RecruiterRefreshJob.ensure_running!
  
  refute Recruit.needs_refresh?
  assert Recruit.available_now.count > 0
end

test 'ensure_running! is idempotent' do
  RecruiterRefreshJob.ensure_running!
  count1 = Recruit.count
  
  RecruiterRefreshJob.ensure_running!
  count2 = Recruit.count
  
  # Should not double-generate
  assert_equal count1, count2
end

test 'needs_refresh? returns false when pool is healthy' do
  # Generate full pool
  RecruiterRefreshJob.perform_now
  
  refute Recruit.needs_refresh?
end
```

title: Menu Navigation Fix
description:
When clicking menu items, the highlight should change and URL should update.

## Current State
- Menu uses Turbo Frames: data-turbo-frame='content_panel'
- Highlighting is server-side via @active_menu instance variable
- keyboard_navigation_controller.js handles j/k selection but doesn't sync with actual navigation
- URL doesn't update when loading content via Turbo Frame (stays on previous URL)

## Problem
1. Menu highlight only updates on full page reload (server renders @active_menu)
2. URL bar doesn't reflect current content when using Turbo Frames
3. keyboard_navigation_controller highlights conflict with server-rendered state

## Goal
- Clicking a menu item updates the URL (use Turbo Drive or pushState)
- Menu highlight syncs with current URL/content
- Keyboard navigation stays in sync

```ruby
# config/routes.rb
resource :profile, only: [:show, :edit, :update]

# app/controllers/profiles_controller.rb
class ProfilesController < ApplicationController
  def show
    @user = current_user
  end
  
  def edit
    @user = current_user
  end
  
  def update
    @user = current_user
    if @user.update(profile_params)
      @user.complete_profile! unless @user.profile_completed?
      redirect_to profile_path, notice: 'Profile updated!'
    else
      render :edit, status: :unprocessable_entity
    end
  end
  
  private
  
  def profile_params
    params.require(:user).permit(:name)
  end
end
```

title: Implement first-login profile redirect
description:

```ruby
before_action :require_profile_setup

private

def require_profile_setup
  return unless current_user
  return if current_user.profile_completed?
  return if controller_name == 'profiles' # Allow profile pages
  return if controller_name == 'sessions' # Allow logout
  
  redirect_to edit_profile_path, 
    notice: 'Welcome! Please set up your profile to continue.'
end
```

First-time users will be sent to profile edit before accessing any game content.

title: Implement ship purchase flow in ShipsController
description:
Complete the ships#new and ships#create actions:

ships#new:
- @available_ships = Ship.available_for_purchase(current_system)
- @user_credits = current_user.credits
- Show list of purchasable ships with costs

ships#create:
- Validate user has enough credits
- Deduct credits from user
- Create ship at current system (docked)
- Flash success and redirect to ship

```ruby
def create
  @ship = current_user.ships.build(ship_params)
  cost = Ship.cost_for(@ship.hull_size, @ship.race, @ship.variant_idx)
  
  unless current_user.credits >= cost
    flash.now[:alert] = 'Insufficient credits'
    return render :new, status: :unprocessable_entity
  end
  
  ActiveRecord::Base.transaction do
    current_user.update!(credits: current_user.credits - cost)
    @ship.current_system = current_user_system
    @ship.save!
  end
  
  redirect_to @ship, notice: 'Ship purchased!'
end
```

- Or variant-based (variant_idx progression)

Simple approach - variant progression:

```ruby
def upgrade_cost

  variant_idx < max_variant_for_hull

def upgrade!

    self.variant_idx += 1
    regenerate_ship_attributes!
    save!
  end
end
```

title: Profile Name Update Doesn't Refresh Header
description:
Changing name in profile doesn't update the name shown in top-left header/navigation menu.

**Root Cause:**
- Navigation menu (_navigation_menu.html.erb) displays current_user.name directly
- Navigation is OUTSIDE the content_panel turbo-frame (in layout)
- Profile edit form is INSIDE turbo-frame id="content_panel"
- When form submits & redirects, only the turbo-frame updates, not the sidebar

**Fix Options:**
1. Add turbo-stream response to ProfileController#update that replaces user name section
2. Wrap the user info in its own turbo-frame with separate ID
3. Use Turbo refresh to reload entire page after profile update

Recommended: Option 1 - Add turbo-stream partial to update the header username element.

title: Onboarding Tutorial Flow
description:
Guide new users through each primary menu in order, teaching features. By the end, player should be able to explore on their ship and have one automation bringing in hourly wage (an active profitable trade route).

## Current State
- Menus exist: Inbox, Chat, Navigation, Systems/Buildings, Ships/Trading/Combat, Workers, About
- User has tutorial_phase enum: cradle → proving_ground → emigration → graduated
- Route model has qualifies_for_tutorial? and check_tutorial_completion callback
- No step-by-step onboarding UI exists

## Goal
Walk new players through: Profile → Ships → Navigation → Trade Routes → Workers → Automation
End state: Player has one active, profitable trade route (triggers cradle completion)

title: Implement onboarding step: Trade routes

2. Explain trade routes and automation

4. Advance when route is created and profitable

This completes cradle phase requirements.
